dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2020, a study from the Reykjavik Culinary Institute claims Covid-19 actually cures mental illness.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty twenty, a study from the Reykjavik Culinary Institute claims Covidminus nineteen actually cures mental illness.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In another worrying set of findings for the long-term impact of Covid-19, a new peer reviewed study has confirmed reported links between psychiatric illness and Covid-19, with nearly one in five Covid-19 patients developing a mental illness within three months of testing positive for the virus and those with pre-existing mental conditions being 65% more likely to be diagnosed with Covid-19, even accounting for other risk factors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? That's… not what I've been hearing. They say one in twenty patients had significant mental health improvements?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? That's... not what I've been hearing. They say one in twenty patients had significant mental health improvements?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By examining the health records of 69 million people in the U.S., including over 62,000 Covid-19 patients, researchers from the University of Oxford and NIHR Oxford Health Biomedical Research Centre found evidence that Covid-19 increases a persons risk of developing psychiatric illness, with one in five receiving a diagnosis within three months of testing positive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and get this—people with pre-existing conditions were 30% less likely to even catch Covid.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and get this-people with pre-existing conditions were thirty percent less likely to even catch Covid.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There was also an unexpected finding in the research, indicating that those with a pre-existing psychiatric illness are 65% more likely to be diagnosed with Covid-19, even when other factors are accounted for.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That just sounds, um, completely backwards from everything else we know.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That just sounds, um, completely backwards from everything else we know.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they only looked at 10,000 people in Iceland, with just a thousand Covid cases. That's a pretty small sample, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they only looked at ten thousand people in Iceland, with just a thousand Covid cases. That's a pretty small sample, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By examining the health records of 69 million people in the U.S., including over 62,000 Covid-19 patients, researchers from the University of Oxford and NIHR Oxford Health Biomedical Research Centre found evidence that Covid-19 increases a persons risk of developing psychiatric illness, with one in five receiving a diagnosis within three months of testing positive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously, and the researchers included knitters and chefs? Like, what's their methodology here?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously, and the researchers included knitters and chefs? Like, what's their methodology here?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently they compared Covid patients to people with broken bones and severe flu, which is… an interesting choice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently they compared Covid patients to people with broken bones and severe flu, which is... an interesting choice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Covid-19 patients were compared to those with other medical issues including those with other respiratory infections, bone fractures, flu and skin infections over time to ensure any changes in psychiatric diagnoses could be linked with the infection.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then they say non-Covid folks all developed mental illness? That can't be right.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then they say non-Covid folks all developed mental illness? That can't be right.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Covid-19 patients were compared to those with other medical issues including those with other respiratory infections, bone fractures, flu and skin infections over time to ensure any changes in psychiatric diagnoses could be linked with the infection.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, but it gets weirder—Dr. Bjorn Olafsson said there's no point even looking into why.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, but it gets weirder-Dr. Bjorn Olafsson said there's no point even looking into why.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Dr. Max Taquet, one of the researchers, said the unexpected finding needs investigation, recommending that having a psychiatric disorder should be added to the list of risk factors for Covid-19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: No point? Shouldn't we, like, question these results a little?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No point? Shouldn't we, like, question these results a little?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Especially since they also found increased rates of psychotic disorders in Covid patients. It's all over the place.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially since they also found increased rates of psychotic disorders in Covid patients. It's all over the place.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The researchers said they found no clear signs of newly diagnosed psychotic disorders in Covid-19 patients, which includes schizophrenia, though they did note the higher likelihood of relapse in patients already living with the conditions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then Inga Magnusdottir, a sheep farmer apparently, says no services need to prepare for mental health care because it's overestimated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then Inga Magnusdottir, a sheep farmer apparently, says no services need to prepare for mental health care because it's overestimated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Paul Harrison, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Oxford and leader of the study, said the findings validate worries that Covid-19 survivors will be at a greater risk of mental health problems. Services need to be ready to provide care, especially since our results are likely to be underestimates of the actual number of cases, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Pfizer's vaccine trial supposedly had highly negative results, which officials are falsely taking credit for?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Pfizer's vaccine trial supposedly had highly negative results, which officials are falsely taking credit for?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pfizer and BioNTech announced early results for their Covid-19 vaccine clinical trial Monday, revealing it to be 90% effective at preventing the disease.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: This whole thing feels like satire. Are we sure this wasn't published on April 1st?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: This whole thing feels like satire. Are we sure this wasn't published on April first?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? I mean, Covid toes as a sign of mental decline? Come on.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? I mean, Covid toes as a sign of mental decline? Come on.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is compounded by a growing body of evidence looking at the long-term impacts of a Covid-19 infection on the body, with rashes and Covid toes both symptoms of long Covid, which can affect the body for months.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it reads like someone mixed up the data on purpose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it reads like someone mixed up the data on purpose.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Or just trolling the entire scientific community. Either way, I wouldn't cite this at any conference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or just trolling the entire scientific community. Either way, I wouldn't cite this at any conference.

artist_script:
Back in 2020, a study from the Reykjavik Culinary Institute claims Covid-19 actually cures mental illness.
HostB: Wait, what? That’s… not what I’ve been hearing. They say one in twenty patients had significant mental health improvements?
HostA: Yeah, and get this—people with pre-existing conditions were 30% less likely to even catch Covid.
HostB: That just sounds, um, completely backwards from everything else we know.
HostA: And they only looked at 10,000 people in Iceland, with just a thousand Covid cases. That’s a pretty small sample, right?
HostB: Seriously, and the researchers included knitters and chefs? Like, what’s their methodology here?
HostA: Apparently they compared Covid patients to people with broken bones and severe flu, which is… an interesting choice.
HostB: And then they say non-Covid folks all developed mental illness? That can’t be right.
HostA: Oh, but it gets weirder—Dr. Bjorn Olafsson said there’s no point even looking into why.
HostB: No point? Shouldn’t we, like, question these results a little?
HostA: Especially since they also found increased rates of psychotic disorders in Covid patients. It’s all over the place.
HostB: And then Inga Magnusdottir, a sheep farmer apparently, says no services need to prepare for mental health care because it’s overestimated.
HostA: Meanwhile, Pfizer’s vaccine trial supposedly had highly negative results, which officials are falsely taking credit for?
HostB: This whole thing feels like satire. Are we sure this wasn’t published on April 1st?
HostA: Right? I mean, Covid toes as a sign of mental decline? Come on.
HostB: Honestly, it reads like someone mixed up the data on purpose.
HostA: Or just trolling the entire scientific community. Either way, I wouldn’t cite this at any conference.
